UNIVERSITY OF SASKATCHEWAN
SASKATOON, SASK.

December 12, 1962

Mrs. Dolly Gush,
219 Vancouver St.,
Victoria, B.C.,

Dear Mrs. Gush:

The Saskatchewan Archives is presently conducting a search for information on pioneer days to add to the permanent historic records of this province. In order to facilitate this search we have prepared a questionnaire which we are asking pioneers to fill in for us. It is intended that the completed questionnaires will be kept permanently and used as reference material for historians conducting research on early history of this province.

Your name has been given us as a person who might be willing to help us by completing the enclosed questionnaire. We will be pleased if you will complete the questionnaire as far as you are able to do so and return it to this office.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

D. H. Rocking,
Assistant Provincial Archivist

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives of the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Dorothy Gush nee Burrows
2. Your address: 219 Homestead St., Victoria BC.
3. Date:

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: George Henry Burrows Taylor
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens" etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?: I came with my father, mother & sister, nurse years older than me. My father was advised to move to Canada for health reasons; to improve a dry climate; needed a dry climate.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: Because with my father & sister, raise years older than me, my father was advised to move to Canada. He needed a dry climate

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Through family friend. They were Pioneers who had moved west in the year of 1904. I heard about it from them.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Some thought we were coming to a country of wild animals + too new ways! Others thought we were coming to a country of opportunity.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Travelled as a family

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Boat + Lumber freight + Railways + Stagecoaches + Horseback

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

There was no Saddle Mountain, was the end of the line. There was no Saddle Mountain, was the end of the line. There was no Saddle Mountain, was the end of the line.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

One night at the Hotel

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

On the 34 & 47 Range 19

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Just Reaped on the farm
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Some thought we would come to Canada as a family.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Travelled as a family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Boat from England to France, then train to Canada.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

The boat was very crowded. The food was not very good. We had to sleep on the floor. There was a lot of rain and mud. We had to change our clothes frequently. We also had to be careful of the wagons and railroad tracks.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I stayed at the Hotel Regina and our family.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

On the Grasslands near the Missouri Valley, N.W.T., Canada.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked on the farm.

Yes, mostly because you came to work at the mine. Also, some people were attracted by the opportunity to build up the community.

35. Did many people return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father, S.H. Burrows, was a Justice of the Peace for many years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

The Hypolite School district was first named in 1890. The first school building was built in 1892. The first teacher was Mrs. Louise Burrows.

The Hygieia School district name was given by Mr. Burrows on our new farm land.
